title: Free-body diagrams - two masses pushed up incline

content.question: Two different blocks, <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, are next to each other on an inclined smooth surface which has negligible friction. An applied force, <math alttext="F sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>P</mi></msub></math>, pushes Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> as shown and the blocks move up the ramp. A student sketch of a free-body diagram representing the forces in this situation is given. Which of the following statements best describes the change, if any, that should be made to this free-body diagram?

choices.label: The <math alttext="F sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>P</mi></msub></math> arrow should be labeled as <math alttext="F sub A B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>AB</mtext></msub></math> for the force that Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> exerts on Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>.
There should be an additional force <math alttext="F sub B A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>BA</mtext></msub></math> pointing down the incline.
Each of the above statements is possible depending on which object or system the free-body diagram represents.

content.answer: Each of the above statements is possible depending on which object or system the free-body diagram represents.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
